Resource.Title: Initial commit
Resource.Text: In the initial commit I only created a single Visual Studio project from the built-in template and the GitHub repository.

Resource.Title: Endpoint and transport layer
Resource.Text: I took the application logic from the template and moved it into an application layer. This layer is split into endpoints and transport. Endpoints only maps routes, while transport contains the logic to handle requests.

Resource.Title: Authentication and authorization
Resource.Text: Some say that one should not use a custom authentication handling. I did it anyway. It uses a token that is hard-coded for now.

Resource.Title: Authentication endpoint
Resource.Text: A sign-in endpoint verifies the user credentials and returns a token. The credentials are still hard-coded and I ignore the existence of OIDC for the time being.

Resource.Title: Authentication through user manager
Resource.Text: Credentials need to be stored in storage. A user manager will give me that option. This manager allows to store generated tokens on every sign-in, but it still contains a hard-coded list of users.

Resource.Title: Authentication endpoint tests
Resource.Text: I added endpoint tests for the sign-in, based on WebApplicationFactory and `xUnit`. Additionally, I did some clean up and moved the user class, which is now called identity, into the data layer.

Resource.Title: Authentication flow routes
Resource.Text: Preliminary definition of routes related to the complete authentication and authorization flow. As usual, the hardest part is the naming, and telling my inner OCD to shut up. ðŸ˜†

Resource.Title: Json authentication badge
Resource.Text: The token, which is returned from the sign-in endpoint, needs to be extendable. It is now evolving into some kind of JWT. I make use of an endpoint filter, that serializes claims into a JSON string, that gets encoded.

Resource.Title: Group member authorization
Resource.Text: First step to make this monolith multitenantable (is that even a word?ðŸ¤”). A second API call, after the sign-in, allows to take-up a group membership. Only users with a group member claim have access to the business logic.

Resource.Title: Authentication alignment to default provider pattern
Resource.Text: After focusing on the authentication a refactoring was needed. I chose to align my authentication provider to the implementation of the default providers from #dotnet. Using an existing pattern might help others to comprehend what is going on.

Resource.Title: Endpoints for identity and member resources
Resource.Text: All endpoints should follow REST for the better part. Simple GET endpoints to query the currently available data have been added. Additionally, the seed data has been moved to the appsettings.

Resource.Title: Request user injection
Resource.Text: Creating a wrapper around the user of the current request helps. It gives me the ability to inject the user into my request handler. Depending on the claims of the user I can control filtering, which results in perfect multitenancy queryability.

Resource.Title: Authentication cache
Resource.Text: A simple byte cache in the data layer is used to store an authentication verification value. During authentication this value is validated against the value in the token. Additionally, some renaming was necessary.

Resource.Title: More authentication endpoint tests
Resource.Text: More authentication endpoint tests. In this example I want to write them from the beginning. We all know that it will pay off. Additional, I moved to `IClaimsTransformation` after meeting it on David Fowler's timeline.ðŸ˜±

Resource.Title: Membership class and manager
Resource.Text: Paving the way to a real data layer. But first I needed to modify the relationship between groups, members and identities. A membership allows for an identity to be bound to multiple members of different groups. One authentication, multiple accounts.

Resource.Title: Repository abstraction
Resource.Text: Repository abstraction is now serving the data for the managers. Everything is still in-memory, but it will help me when I introduce an ORM.

Resource.Title: Repository configuration
Resource.Text: Setup of the initial repository data is now served via an insertion, instead of an injected dependency. The repository hides data store from the seed data, which allows to switch the data store to an ORM in the future.

Resource.Title: Snowflakes
Resource.Text: It's Christmas season, that's why I implemented some snowflakes with the help of Rob Janssen's IdGen package. Snowflake IDs will become the primary keys in the database.

Resource.Title: Member creation endpoint with validation
Resource.Text: Up until now no validation had been implemented. I added an endpoint that allows to create new members. The validation takes place in the management layer, right before calling the repository insert.

Resource.Title: Shared validation
Resource.Text: Validation is such an essential element that it makes sense to think about it a bit more. I implemented a shared validation component that does not depend on an external library. I want full control over the validation.

Resource.Title: Repository and endpoint asynchronicity
Resource.Text: Slowly extending the repository. Asynchronicity is key when talk to a database. With the static dictionary currently used this may not be exactly true, but it will become important once I switch to an ORM.

Resource.Title: Atomic bulk delete
Resource.Text: Bulk deletions in the repository can be tricky, when the operation needs to be atomic. In the current static dictionary implementation I solve this requirement by using [SemaphoreSlim](https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/main/src/libraries/System.Private.CoreLib/src/System/Threading/SemaphoreSlim.cs).

Resource.Title: Put endpoints and repository update methods
Resource.Text: For the update method in the repository, I use an `Action` which will modify the entity. I will not support real bulk updates yet. After [#29654](https://github.com/dotnet/efcore/issues/29654) is implemented, I will have another look for an additional update method.

Resource.Title: Request error status codes
Resource.Text: Simple adjustments add some generic error handling. It uses [problem details](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc7807) and supports swagger. Standardized support for error messages allows clients to use a generic error handling as well.

Resource.Title: Endpoint error messages and entity clones
Resource.Text: Endpoint error messages help to increase the usefulness of the problem details. Additionally, it turned out that I forgot that the temporary static dictionary data provider does not cope well with update actions. I needed to make all entities `ICloneable`.

Resource.Title: Role requirements
Resource.Text: [Role requirements](https://github.com/cschulzsuper/multitenancy-monolith/blob/main/docs/ROLES.md) restrict endpoint access for authenticated identities and members. Security tests as part of endpoint tests ensure this permanently.

Resource.Title: Client authentication
Resource.Text: [Client requirement](https://github.com/cschulzsuper/multitenancy-monolith/blob/main/docs/CLIENTS.md) in authentication and authorization request will later allow a restricted usage of badges.

Resource.Title: Swagger restriction
Resource.Text: Only clients that authenticate as `swagger` client can access the `swagger.json` in production. In development this restriction is not applied. A security tests verifies the behavior.

Resource.Title: Swagger UI access token interception
Resource.Text: A nice gem is to make the swagger ui available in staging environments with the necessity of providing an access token for it.

Resource.Title: Domain specific swagger files
Resource.Text: Maybe it is nice for clients to have separated swagger files. I grouped endpoints by domains (`authentication`, `administration`, `business`, `foundation`) and provide a swagger file for each of them.

Resource.Title: Custom property management endpoints
Resource.Text: How about the ability to add custom properties to REST resources. I have defined management API for this feature, and regrouped the endpoints once again.

Resource.Title: Custom property management
Resource.Text: Major commit. The complete draft to manage custom properties including all endpoint tests and some improvements to the validation logic. An example business object endpoint is also implemented.

Resource.Title: Business object custom properties
Resource.Text: Completion of custom properties for the business objects example entity. Refactoring of the repository service factories and extension of the entity constrains assertion in the repository.

Resource.Title: Endpoint test error message assertion infrastructure
Resource.Text: Draft implementation to assert the error messages in the endpoint tests. Static classes are used to define the error messages.

Resource.Title: Problem detail status code improvements
Resource.Text: Extending the exception handling to allow better status codes in problem details. The status codes are asserted in the endpoint tests.

Resource.Title: Ticker service
Resource.Text: A hard test on my architecture. At some point the monolith will be separated. A ticket service the runs as a secondary service. ðŸ¤” That was the easy part, the hard part was restructuring authentication and all endpoint tests again.

Resource.Title: Configuration component
Resource.Text: The separation of services caused hard coded urls as part of `Cors` and `Swagger`. Introducing components that provide configurations to the rest of the application will help to keep it flexibil.

Resource.Title: Ticker user confirm
Resource.Text: A confirm flow makes it possible to authenticate once as a ticker user before it is necessary to confirm the ticker user. An integration tests ensures the flow always succeeds.

Resource.Title: Ticker user post
Resource.Text: A special `/post` endpoint allows a user to create a new ticker message. It is automatically created for his ticker user.

Resource.Title: Event storage abstraction
Resource.Text: An event storage abstraction allows publishing events from different places. The first implementation logs the events. Usage of `ITestOutputHelper` makes it possible to see the logs in the tests.

Resource.Title: Channel based event pub/sub
Resource.Text: Lightweight events via `System.Threading.Channels` and migration to `net8.0`. This event implementation should be enough for the moment. I'm kind of glad that I focused on tests early on. Green on all `683`.

Resource.Title: Multitenancy event processing
Resource.Text: Multitenancy events. This kind of implemenation is not my cup of tea, as some asynchronouse task handling is going on, but all tests give me the confidence that the implementaion is sufficient for now.

Resource.Title: Event publication interception
Resource.Text: Event publication interception for testability of event publication. Not a perfect solution for now, but it will work until I come up with something better.

Resource.Title: Ticker bookmark
Resource.Text: Handling the `ticker-message-inserted` to automatically create a bookmark for the current ticker user. Testing this event handler in an event tests, which is similar to the endpoint tests.

Resource.Title: Ticker bookmark endpoints
Resource.Text: Managing bookmarks for ticker messages is possible through simple endpoints. Nothing fancy in this commit.

Resource.Title: Ticker user endpoints
Resource.Text: Managing ticker users via endpoints was not necessary until now. Again, nothing fancy in this commit as well.

Resource.Title: Ticker user reset
Resource.Text: Resetting the secret of a ticker user was an easy implementation. Mainly, because of the foundation that was implemented in all other commits.

Resource.Title: Ticker message bookmarking
Resource.Text: Productive day. The last bit in the ticker orchestration is the flagging of the ticker bookmark updated flag after the ticker message has been changed or deleted.

Resource.Title: Authorization and authentication prefixing
Resource.Text: Introduction of prefixes for groups, members and identities. The new resources are `account-groups`, `account-members` and `authentication-identities`. Renaming of all related classes.

Resource.Title: Account group endpoints
Resource.Text: The missing `account-groups` endpoint is implemented. With tests and some additional renaming that was forgotten in the previous commit.

Resource.Title: Account group and authentication identity HTTP HEAD endpoints
Resource.Text: `HTTP HEAD` requests check for used `account-groups` and `authentication-identities`. Additionally, registration object definition for  `authentication-identities` and `account-groups`. They will be used in registration flows.

Resource.Title: Account and authentication registration endpoints
Resource.Text: Registration endpoints for `authentication-identities` and `account-groups`. Not much more this time, apart from smaller code improvements. Seal classes whenever you can!

Resource.Title: Account and authentication registration confirmation
Resource.Text: Registration flow components continues! This time confirmation and approval.

Resource.Title: Account and authentication registration resource endpoints
Resource.Text: Implemented resource endpoints to manage `account-registration` and `authentication-registration`. Also renamed the `administration` domain to `extension`.

Resource.Title: Ticker bookmark events
Resource.Text: Fixes to produce a testable state. Refactored `Repository` to be able to trigger `ticker-bookmark` events. Evaluation of `ticker-bookmark` events in `ticker` integration tests. Changed and fixed JSON serialization of `IDictionary<string, object>` when serialized in asynchronous context.

Resource.Title: Ticker bookmark confirm
Resource.Text: Added `confirm` endpoint, logic and related tests to unmark `ticker-bookmark`. Changed event handler project name from `Events` to `Subscriptions`.

Resource.Title: Sequential jobs
Resource.Text: First draft of a very simple background job component, that exeutes jobs sequentially in a `HostedService`. For now, only simple logging heartbeat is implemented.

Resource.Title: Job update endpoint
Resource.Text: An HTTP PUT endpoint allows to change the schedule of a background job. Additionally, a changes were necessary to fix the swagger client and the authentication.

Resource.Title: Job management
Resource.Text: Entity and management to store the job schedule in the data layer. Additionally, changes in the validation.

Resource.Title: Job endpoints, logic and renaming
Resource.Text: Renamed `job` to `planned-job`, implemented endpoints and tests related to background jobs.

Resource.Title: Claims transformation
Resource.Text: Migration to the new [bearer token authentication](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/microsoft.extensions.dependencyinjection.bearertokenextensions.addbearertoken?view=aspnetcore-8.0) of .NET 8 started, but this first step is only a build-up. I moved the `Claim` mapping from my custom authentication to the `ClaimsTransformation`.

Resource.Title: Bearer token authentication
Resource.Text: First draft with the refactored authentication. I was able to remove most of the code from the custom authentication I used before. I will probably iterate over it once more, but the first implementation seems to work.

Resource.Title: Bearer token finalization
Resource.Text: Some cleanup after the refactoring. I also removed all hard-coded URLs and fixed usings and namespaces.

Resource.Title: Dockerfile swagger client
Resource.Text: Kick-off for the `docker-compose` support. I added a `Dockerfile` to the `Swagger` client and optimized a little bit of code in it.

Resource.Title: Dockerfile server and ticker
Resource.Text: `Dockerfile` for `server` and `ticker`, and aditionally a component to add `SwaggerDocs` only if the corresponding `swagger.json` endpoint is available.

Resource.Title: Docker compose
Resource.Text: Puh. A first `docker-compose.yml` is now integrated. Too have easy configuration of ports and host, I had to change some things in the configuration. There will be more `Docker` stuff, and I also have the feeling, that the configuration will change again.

Resource.Title: Swagger sign-in redirect
Resource.Text: It took me a bit, and I'm still amazed that it is actually working. I added the groundwork for a sign-in. For now, this is located in the `Swagger` project, and it is only a simple redirect, with credentials from the configuration. While implementing this, I also refactored quite a bit in the web service layer.

Resource.Title: Swagger sign-in blazor SSR
Resource.Text: I turned the `Swagger` project into a .NET 8 Blazor SSR. The same redirect code, that was previously in the `sign-in` endpoint is now in a simple `sign-in` page.

Resource.Title: Swagger sign-in page 'n style
Resource.Text: A very minimalistic Blazor SSR `sign-in` page that still has some issues caused by .NET 8 preview 7, but I'm satisfied with this first implementation.

Resource.Title: Swagger sign-in additional port
Resource.Text: Changed some minor things. The biggest change is an additional port mapping for the `Swagger` client. I use this temporarily to make sure that the Blazor SSR does a full reload for the Swagger UI redirect after the sign-in.

Resource.Title: Portal and dev-diary frontend
Resource.Text: I have not touched the seed data implementation for quite a while, but the moment has arrived to give it a much-needed overhaul. Beyond its existing applications, I plan to integrate it into a development diary. In a first step, I've separated the sign-in functionality from the `Swagger` project and moved it into a new frontend layer.

Resource.Title: Dev-diary posts design
Resource.Text: I'm sticking to the wireframe styles, when it comes to the development diary. This was more pain than gain, given my limited interest in UI/UX design.

Resource.Title: Development post seed data
Resource.Text: Given that I'm not a thirteen-year-old girl, I renamed the development diary to development log. A new seed data implementation is used for its data. Additionally, the management and the data layer for the log have been implemented.

Resource.Title: Seed data refactoring
Resource.Text: The old seed data provider is gone, and I also changed other things related to the configuration, that is provided via `appsettings.json`. I will fill the development log, when I have something deployable.

Resource.Title: Nginx
Resource.Text: I'm not an expert when it comes to nginx, so this is just some early script kiddy experiment. I added an nginx container with a simple nginx.conf. Adjustments in the API routes and `<base>` tags where necessary. It seems to work.

Resource.Title: Bearer token simplification
Resource.Text: After the recent _Bearer Token Refactoring_, I had to evaluate, if the `verification` keys, that are stored in the token, are still needed. The build-in `DataProtection` secures the token for my needs quite well. I decided now, to remove everthing releted to the `verification` and also made the token validation much simpler.

Resource.Title: Sign-In split
Resource.Text: At some point in the future I want a more flexible sign-in. That sign-in should support MFA. In a first step I decieded to split the `sign-in` page in two steps. One for the username and one for the password.

Resource.Title: Caddy reverse proxy
Resource.Text: Why use only one reverse proxy if you can have two. Caddy seems to have good build-in SSL handling and can retriev certificates from [Let's Encrypt](https://letsencrypt.org/) automatically. From now on, _Caddy_ will terminate SSL. Since this was very easy to integrate, I wanted to push this while I'm working on the _Sign-In Extension_.

Resource.Title: Deployment hacks
Resource.Text: I wanted the [dev-log](https://mmdevlogapp.azurewebsites.net/dev-log) to be available on the web. I played around with multiple options for the deployment, and ended up with simple Azure Web Apps. This option is enough for now. It alone brought some TODO's to light, which first need to be sorted out. If anybody ever tells you, that you should not implement your own authentication, listen to him. Nevertheless, I will stick with my custom authentication, as it actually forced me to understand how OIDC and OAuth do things.

Resource.Title: Anonymouse authentication
Resource.Text: A guest sign-in is possible for everybody who does not want to sign-in with credentials. The guest sign-in still goes through authentication, but an extension of the data model allows to authenticate anonymously. The anonymous authentication method is used for the demo account for now.

Resource.Title: History transfer
Resource.Text: With the finesse of a typographer and the magic of [Markdig](https://github.com/xoofx/markdig) and [Humanizer](https://github.com/Humanizr/Humanizer), I transformed the history from the `README.md` into lively posts for this **Development Log**. Dates became **`yesterday`** and **`a week ago`**, and numeric data turned poetic. The result? An enchanting narrative.

Resource.Title: Redis
Resource.Text: The deployment used a dirty hack to support [DataProtection-Keys]( https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/aspnet/core/security/data-protection/configuration/overview) across multiple services. I'm fixing this now with the help of a [Redis](https://hub.docker.com/r/redis/redis-stack) server. This container is running as [Azure Container Instance](https://azure.microsoft.com/de-de/products/container-instances/).

Resource.Title: Sqlite repository
Resource.Text: Finally, I began work on an [EF Core](https://github.com/dotnet/efcore) data layer. It is based on my `IRepository` abstraction and temporarily on the [SQLite Provider](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/ef/core/providers/sqlite). The initial version supports query operations and is exclusively used by the `dev-log`.

Resource.Title: Sqlite repository continuation
Resource.Text: Continuing the work on the EF Core based data layer. Implementation of `Insert`, `Update` and `Delete` methods in the `Repository`, Models for `admission` entities, and bugfixing all tests.

Resource.Title: Ticker obsolete
Resource.Text: Removed the ticker service as I want to focus on the core of the application. The ticker was an experiment and nothing more. I hope that change will boost motivation for this project.

Resource.Title: Multitenancy sqlite repository
Resource.Text: Migrated the `Access` domain to use the EF Core Sqlite data layer. This included support for multitenancy. I also fixed some tests and the error handling to respect `UNIQUE CONSTRAINT` exceptions.

Resource.Title: Pre-Build build-info
Resource.Text: A generic pre-build tool can be used to read git information like branch name and commit hash. It creates a build info JSON file, which can be used by projects to devliver version information.
